newsitem.title: SWEDEN: P&U falls as EPS estimates cut 5-10 pct.
newsitem.headline: P&U falls as EPS estimates cut 5-10 pct.

text.p: The continuing woes of Swedish-U.S. drug company Pharmacia & Upjohn depressed its share price further on Thursday as analysts cut forecasts by up to 10 percent following a weaker-than-expected second quarter.

P&U, formed through the 1995 merger of Pharmacia of Sweden and the U.S. Upjohn, posted earnings on Tuesday per share (EPS) of $0.34 for the second quarter, down from $0.51 a year before and below market expectations of $0.36.
After rebounding four crowns and 5.5 crowns respectively on the two days following the report, the share slipped back on Thursday, shedding seven crowns to 296.5 by 1400 GMT.
"The more people had a chance to look at it, the less they liked what they saw," said pharmaceuticals analyst Jeff Chaffkin at PaineWebber in New York.
PaineWebber has cut its EPS estimates to $1.50 from $1.60 for calendar 1997 and to $1.75 from $1.95 for 1998.
Chaffkin said portfolio managers used to regard the share as one of the cheaper drug stocks, lagging behind its rivals after a series of profit warnings over the past 10 months.
But closer inspection unveiled stubborn problems.
"The major driver behind reduced earnings estimates is the much higher costs of goods sold," Chaffkin said. "These problems are not easy fixes."
Several analysts said the share was in for a rough ride as generic products eroded product prices, especially in the U.S.
Janet Dyson, pharmaceuticals analysts at Merrill Lynch, said she had lowered her EPS estimates for the year to $1.45 from $1.60 before the report, and to $1.70 for 1998 from $1.85.
"We still don't think the difficulties in the generic business have bottomed out. The amount coming in for new drugs is not substantial enough to offset generic pressure," Dyson told Reuters.
P&U said in its half-year report that many of its products continued to face competition from generic brands.
"This price erosion has balanced out all their cost savings," said Handelsbanken analyst Stefan Wikholm. "The market thought price erosion may level out, but it's continued."
Wikholm has lowered his EPS estimates for 1997 to $1.64 from $1.78 and for 1998 to $2.10 from $2.31.
BNP Capital Markets analyst Ian Broadhurst told Reuters he had cut his EPS estimates for 1997 to $1.60 from $1.70 and to $1.80 from $2.10 for 1998.
Analysts said they would examine details of advertised cost cuts very closely.
P&U said on Tuesday it would publish a progress report in the fourth quarter, and some further job losses to be expected.

The company said it would have to take some extraordinary restructuring charges in addition to a charge of 10-16 cents a share in the third quarter for merging P&U's Pharmacia Biotech unit with a division of British Amersham International Plc . Some analysts saw this as another profit warning.
Newly appointed chief executive Fred Hassan has his work cut out to meet his expectations of a turnaround in 1998, Chaffkin said.
"I expect not just (cuts) on the administration side but also in R&D and acceleration of plant consolidation and of the plant closure schedule," Chaffkin said.
